posts.name: Ankur Raghavan
posts.cooked:
We experience very slow startups on our CANivore (>1 min). This also doesn’t let the code finish booting. Once it boots, it is solidly on and has no issues. If code restarts or is uploaded, it has no issues.

The lights are green, off, off, orange and switch to green, off, off, green once fully booted.

We didn’t really care because once it’s up it’s fine, but some teams said that this is uncharacteristic behavior for the canivore. We currently run a separate can bus for our drivetrain than the rest of the bot.

posts.name: Luke
posts.cooked: I don’t know about other teams, but this is pretty similar to what my team has been experiencing. We’re also running a separate bus for absolute encoders on our swerve modules, but they’re only called at the start of the code to zero the relative encoders on the steering motors. We just have someone stay on the field until the light is flashing green to confirm that there aren’t any issues, but it is a bit annoying. For most matches we’ve been powering the robot on while it’s still on the cart to offset the long boot time, but if anyone has other solutions to make it boot faster it would be appreciated.

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked:
Ankur-Raghavan:

The lights are green, off, off, orange and switch to green, off, off, green once fully booted.

When the CANivore LEDs are blinking, regardless of color, the CANivore itself is already fully booted. However, the STAT LED can only switch to green once the roboRIO is fully booted and the robot program starts running and enables CANivore CAN streaming (which takes a few ms at program startup). So what you’re seeing is more likely how long it takes for the roboRIO to boot and the robot program to start running.

The CANivore also cannot prevent the code from booting, unless configs are failing in robotInit() with a long timeout (default is 50 ms), or if you’re otherwise doing some kind of loop checking for StatusCode.isOK() . Keep in mind that robot code does not go green in the DS until robotInit() finishes execution (after all config applies).

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: Have you timed how long RobotContainer.generateAutoCommand takes?

posts.name: Ankur Raghavan
posts.cooked: No, but that doesn’t run on startup, that runs on a driver input (in disabled before the match). Anecdotally it causes loop overruns for under 1 second
